loans.name: Muhsin

texts.en:
E. Muhsin is 29 years old. Muhsin is married with three children of school age. 

Muhsin has been selling perfumes in the local market for 12 years. Being the main bread-winner in his family, Muhsin works hard and trys not to lose any advantages in the market. Thus, knowing that Woman Day is coming soon, Muhsin has decided to take a chance and purchase a large lot for purchase for selling. He is sure he shall generate considerable income that he shall use for his family needs and improving living conditions. So he requests $1,000.00 US dollars for the term of 6 months. Having already proved himself as an honest reliable client, Muhsin promises to repay the loan promptly and thanks all for their support.

loans.use: To increase perfume inventory

loans.name: Zawadi

texts.en:
Zawadi is 36 years old, married, with five children, between the ages of 6 to 18. She and her husband also take care of four other people. In 2005, Zawadi started a grocery store and she works there everyday from 6am to 6pm. She can earn an estimated monthly profit of $290 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more food items for her business.

loans.use: To buy more food items

loans.name: Khusni

texts.en:
A. Khusni is 48 years old. Khusni is married with 1 child who already studies at the University. 

Khusni sells kids clothing. She has been running the business for 11 years and works hard to keep it successful and generating stable income for her family. Four times a month Khusni travels to the neighboring city of Ura-Tube to buy the new goods to diversify her inventory and meet the needs of her clientele. 

Khusni has been loaned by IMON for several times already. She has proved herself as a reliable client.  Khusni requests $650.00 US Dollars for the term of 6 months. She is planning to purchase the new inventory for the spring season. Khusni promises to pay the loan in time and thanks all for their support.

loans.use: To purchase new clothing for kids for the spring season.

loans.name: Jhoely

texts.en: Jhoely, a twenty-one year old budding entrepreneur and mother of three children, lives in the Batey of Palavé community of San Cristobal where she operates a small business in order to make a living. Jhoely prepares homemade sweets and candies that she sells throughout the community. The entrepreneur explains that her production is still limited, but she plans on using her loan to expand the business and to produce a wider range of sweets so that she can attract more people. Jhoely’s business supports her children's educations.

loans.use: Jhoely would like to expand her small business selling sweets and candies.

loans.name: Abdurahim

texts.en:
I. Abdurahim is 54 years old. He with his wife had raised three children. 

Abdurahim is a farmer. He grows rice. Today after having experience in this business for 28 years, Abdurahim knows almost everything connected with the process of producing rice. At the same time Abdurahim sells rice in one of the markets. He is selling rice which is not separated from its husks as such rice can be stored for a longer period of time. 

Abdurahim is planning to purchase mineral fertilizer required for growing rice. With this purpose he requests $600.00 US dollars for the term of 6 months. Being loaned for the first time, Abdurahim is sure he shall be able to pay the loan in a timely manner.

loans.use: To purchase mineral fertilizer required for producing rice.

loans.name: Arif

texts.en: A. Arif is  a 39-year-old farmer who has been selling dairy products to the local bazaar traders since 2000. He lives with his wife and son in a small village in the  Saatli region. He applied for 1200 USD to purchase 20 sheep for 60 USD each. Mutton is in very high demand all across Azerbaijan and people use mutton in their every-day life. Arif believes that it will help him  improve the living conditions for his family.

loans.use: To purchase 20 sheep

loans.name: Uktam

texts.en:
I. Uktam is 30 years old. He is married with three children.

Uktam grows rice. When he was a boy he used to help his father who is also involved in this business. When he became an adult, Uktam decided to grow rice also as he already knew lots of things about producing rice theoretically as well as practically. Uktam sell the rice in the local market. Being taught by his father that the storage of the rice is much easier when it is not separated from its husks, Uktam uses this practice also. Working hard, Uktam tries to make his business successful and stable as it generates the main income for the family. 

Uktam would like to purchase mineral fertilizer required for growing rice. He requests $600.00 US dollars for the term of 6 months. This is his first loan from IMON, but Uktam promises to manage the loan with accuracy and remit all payments in a timely manner.

loans.use: To purchase mineral fertilizer required for growing rice.

loans.name: Mirzakhuseyn

texts.en: M. Mirzakhuseyn is a 52-year-old farmer who breeds horses the small village of Saatli. He is married and has four children. This family is vulnerable and it is very hard to cover family needs. Mirzakhuseyn has more than 10 years of experience in this field. He purchases small foasl, raise them  and then  sell them to the local farmers. He applied for 1200 USD and will purchase four foals for 250 USD each and fodder for the rest..

loans.use: To purchase four foals

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Aqroinvest Credit Union - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Magdalena's Upendo Group

texts.en:
Salome P. is 33 years old, married, with three children, ages 17, 15 and 11. Salome owns a small hardware shop that she started in 2005. Everyday, she works from 6am to 7pm and can earn a monthly profit of approximately $70 from her sales.

In the past, Salome has taken out one successful loan from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business. She now hopes for a loan to buy more food items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup member who has a small business as a food vendor.

loans.use: To expand her business

loans.name: Gulali

texts.en: F. Gulali is a 55-year-old farmer who has been selling milk and yoghurt to the local bazaar traders for six years. He lives with his family in the small village of Saatli.  He has five children and as selling milk is the only one financial source in his family it is very hard to cover family needs. For the purpose of improving the life conditions of his family, Gulali has applied for 1200 USD to purchase two additional cows.

loans.use: To purchase two cows

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Aqroinvest Credit Union - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: María Del Carmen

texts.en: María is in her late fifties, and she is an experienced and many-sided entrepreneur. María sells sweets and candies to people of the Batey Palavé community of San Cristobal. She also sells a wide collection of bedspreads, curtains and shoes in the same community. She explains that she’ll press on toward her main goal, which is to buy a comfortable house so that her five children can live at ease. She hopes that her business can turn into a ‘Big Store’ with so many customers that she’ll have to hire many employees to attend to them.

loans.use: Maria would like to purchase bedspreads, curtains and other goods to restock her small business.

loans.name: Akif

texts.en: Qurbanova Akif is a 44-year-old trader who sells fruits and vegetables in the local bazaar in his small village Sarijalar in the Saatli region. He has six years of experience in this field.  Now he needs 1100 USD to improve  the conditions in which to keep fruits and vegetables.

loans.use: To improve the conditions for keeping fruits and vegetables

loans.name: Alifaga

texts.en: I. Alifaga is a 48-year-old trader at the Saatli local bazaar who sells fruits, vegetables, nuts and dried fruits. He has been doing this for thew past eight years. He is married and has three children. He needs 1200 USD to build a good store and continue trading.

loans.use: To build a good store

loans.name: Bimarguba

texts.en:
S. Bimarguba is 34 years old. Sis he is married with three children of school age. 

Bimarguba has been selling women's clothing in the local market for the last five years. Bimarguba started her business having just a few funds at her disposal. Initially she sold the clothing for kids. She was working hard. With time she came to the conclusion that it was more profitable to sell clothing for women. Bimarguba is very friendly with her clientele allowing her to make her business stable, generating significant income for the family. 

Bimarguba woudl like to purchase the new inventory for the spring season. She requests $1,000 .00 US dollars for the term of 6 months. Bimarguba had already proved herself as a reliable client and promises to repay the current loan promptly.

loans.use: To purchase more women's clothes for the spring season.

loans.name: Asha's Tunyanyuane Group

texts.en:
Rose K. is 40 years old and married with four children, ages 21, 17, 14 and 10. Rose owns a small grocery store that she started in 2005. Everyday, she works from 6am to 7pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $140 from her sales.

In the past, Rose has taken out one successful loan from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business. She now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members who have businesses in marketing, food vending and managing a saloon.

loans.use: To expand her business

loans.name: Rufina

texts.en: Rufina, a very kind and persistent woman, lives with her four-year-old boy in the Batey Palavé community of San Cristobal. Rufina prepares decorative candles. She explains that to prepare the candles, she needs a lot of materials such as wax, essence, aroma oils and so forth. Rufina has a well established clientele, and currently her candles are on high demand. She is requesting a loan to invest in the purchase of raw materials in order to prepare more candles and satisfy her customers’ needs. Rufina wants to improve her family’s living conditions.

loans.use: Rufina would like to purchase raw materials to produce decorative candles.

loans.name: Lucy

texts.en:
Lucy is a 30 year old divorced woman with a six-year-old child. Lucy owns a food vending store that she started in 2006. Everyday, she works from 6am to 7pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $45 from her sales.

In the past, Lucy has taken out one successful loan from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business. She now hopes for a loan to buy more food items for her business.

loans.use: To buy more food items for her business.

loans.name: Martha

texts.en: Martha is twenty-seven years old and she has four children, three of them boys. Martha has been selling a collection of fashionable jeans to men and women of the Batey of Palavé community of San Cristobal. Until now, she has been operating her business from her house, but she plans on renting a locale before long to run her activity. Martha will use her loan to expand the business and add an assortment of sneakers and blouses.  That way, the entrepreneur will attract more people and increase her income. Martha wants to provide a comfortable lifestyle with her family.

loans.use: Martha would like to purchase some sneakers and blouses in order to expand her small business.

loans.name: Abdushukur

texts.en:
Kodirov Abdushukur is 37 years old. Abdushukur and his wife are raising three children. 

Abdushukur is a cattleman. He has been raising cattle for about 13 years. Currently he has 3 cows and 3 sheep. Abdushukur is working hard. His kids are getting older and their needs are growing. He dreams to be able to provide his children with everything they need. The business is quite stable and generates the main income for the family. 

Abdushukur has savings, but needs additional funds to purchase 1 bull and 3 sheep. He requests $600.00 US dollars for the term of 6 months. This is the first loan of Abdushsukur and he thanks all supporting him for their trust and promises to repay in time.

loans.use: To purchase 1 bull and 3 sheep.

loans.name: Steria

texts.en:
Steria, 40 years old, is married with four children, ages 22, 18, 14 and 12. Steria owns a small shop that she started in 2004. Everyday, she works from 6am to 7pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $60 from her sales.

In the past, Steria has taken out one successful loan from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business. She now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business.

loans.use: To buy more items for her business.

loans.name: Yuberki

texts.en: Yuberki is a twenty-two year old single woman and she sells women’s clothing and beauty products in the Batey of Palavé community of San Cristobal. Yuberki has already finished secondary school and wants to attend a university. She explains that public university is located at Santo Domingo, the capital, and that she’ll need money to travel outside her community daily to attend classes. Yuberki says she will keep working very hard to achieve her goal. With her loan, the entrepreneur will buy more goods in order to satisfy her customers’ needs and increase her income.

loans.use: Yuberki would like to purchase clothing and beauty products to restock her small business.

loans.name: Abdukahhor

texts.en:
S. Abdukahhor is 49 years old. He and his wife have raised three children. 

For the last 9 years Abdukahhor has been selling shoes for women in the local central market. Abdukahhor’s son and wife help him in running the business. The wife travels to purchase the goods and his son helps him sell in the market (his son is in the picture). Initially when Abdukahhor started the business, he purchased shoes in a neighboring city.  Now, as the business expanded Abdukahhor's wife travels to China for this purpose. In general the business has been successful generating a stable income for the family. 

Now Abdukahhor plans to purchase more women's shoes. He requests $1,000.00 US Dollars for the term of 6 months.  Already having proven himself as a reliable client Abdukahhor promises to repay the current loan promptly.

loans.use: To purchase new women's shoes.

loans.name: Ritha's Ushirika Group

texts.en:
Ritha, 37 years old, started selling clothes in 2004. Everyday, she works from 6am to 7pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $60 from her sales.

In the past, Ritha has taken out one successful loan from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business. She now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business.

loans.use: To buy more items for her business

loans.name: Ritha's Ushirika Group

texts.en:
Ritha is 37 years old and is single woman. Ritha sales clothes, she started in 2004. Everyday, she works from 6am to 7pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $60 from her sales.

In the past, Ritha has taken out 1successful loan from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business. She now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business.

loans.use: To buy more items for her business.

loans.name: Kompong Kor I Group

texts.en: This is a loan which will be shared between twenty-two members of the Kompong Kor I Village Bank in Kandal Province. Mrs. Reth P., age 38, is the Village Bank President. She has two children who are looking for work, and now she and the Village Bank would like to request a loan in order to buy fertilizer, fuel, and hire a person to help her work in her rice field. AdditionalL., she would use the loan to buy pig food.

loans.use: Buy fertilizer, fuel and pig food

payments.comment: Reth Par, Peourk Ros, Sok Ngim Khan, Srey Long, Sokhom Peak, Peourk Ros, Phar Sun, Nan Heang, Sieng Som have each fully paid off their portions of the group loan. The rest of the members of this group have paid off half of their portions.

loans.name: Fatuma's Jitihada Group

texts.en:
Fatuma is 28 years old and married with one child, age 7. In 2004, Fatuma opened her own saloon and she works from 6am to 8pm at her business everday. She can earn a monthly profit of about $70 from her sales.

In the past, Fatuma has taken out one successful loan from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business. She now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup member, who have business dealing in timber selling.

loans.use: To expand business

loans.name: Kulwa's Baraka Group

texts.en:
Josophine is 32 years old, married, with two children, ages 10 and 7. Josophine owns a food vending store that she started in 2006. Everyday, she works from 6am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $45 from her sales.

In the past, Josophine has taken out a successful loan from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business. She now hopes for a loan to buy more food items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members who have businesses in food and timber sales.

loans.use: To buy more food items

loans.name: Hosptial East D Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Rebecca N.. She is currently in the business of maize milling and is requesting a loan to purchase more maize. Rebecca is 23 years old and is single. Each week, Rebecca makes approximately UGX 40000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to buy more maize to make flour. Rebecca has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 200000 in order to add in maize milling business and the loan was paid back on time.

Rebecca is joined in her small group by Lydia M. and Margret B.. Lydia M. has a business in beauty salon and wants to buy more salon equipment like oils, and braids. Margret B. is currently operating a business in charcoal selling and wants a loan to boost business.

loans.use: To boost maize milling business

loans.name: Hosptial East D Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Rebecca N.. She is currently in the business of milling maize and is requesting a loan to purchase more maize. Rebecca is 23 years old and is single. Each week, Rebecca makes approximately UGX 40000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to buy more maize to make flour. Rebecca has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 200000 in order to expand her maize milling business and the loan was paid back on time.

Rebecca is joined in her small group by Lydia M. and Margret B.. Lydia M. has a business running a beauty salon and wants to buy more salon equipment like oils and braids. Margret B. is currently operating a business selling charcoal and wants a loan to boost business.

loans.use: To boost business of milling maize

loans.name: Bwase East A Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Rose K.. She is currently in the business of poultry farming and is requesting a loan to add to her business. Rose is 30 years old and is married. Her husband sells chicken feed for work. She has 1 child aged 10 who goes to school. Each week, Rose makes approximately UGX 30000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to put up better poultry houses. Rose has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX in order to buy chicken business and the loan was paid back on time.

Rose is joined in her small group by Suzan N. and Madina K.. Suzan N. has a business in grocery and wants to increase stock. Madina K. is currently operating a business in sugarcane growing and wants a loan to expand business.

loans.use: To boost poultry business and make more profits

loans.name: Bwase East B Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Joan N.. She is currently in the business of operating a drug shop and is requesting a loan to purchase more drugs to sell. Joan is 29 years old and is married. Her husband is a newspaper vendor. She has 2 children who are 8 and 10, and both of her children go to school. Each week, Joan makes approximately UGX 25000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to purchase more drugs and clinical equipment. Joan has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 350000 in order to buy more drugs and the loan was paid back on time.

Joan is joined in her small group by Prossy N. and Edith K.. Prossy N. has a business running a beauty parlor and wants to expand business. Edith K. is currently operating a business milling maize and wants a loan to purchase more maize.

loans.use: To expand drug shop business

loans.name: Cavid

texts.ru:
Cavid X. was born in year 1978. He currently lives in Agsu region. He has been raising farm animals for the past five years. Cavil is planning to get married soon. He would like to expand his business. This is why he wrote a loan request to the NorMicro microcredit agency of Agsu region. He needs help.

Translated from Russian by Anna Startseva, Kiva volunteer.

Халилов Джавид родился 1978 года рождения. В данный момент проживает в Ахсуниском районе. Пять лет подряд занимается скотоводством. Джавид скоро собирается женится. Этот молодой человек хочеть расширять свой бизнес. Он написал заявление в Нормикро Ахсуниский филиал. Ему надо помочь.

loans.use: To increase the quantity of animals

loans.name: Bwase East C Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Rose M.. She is currently in the business of operating a beauty salon and is requesting a loan to purchase a hair dryer. Rose is 21 years old and is single. Each week, Rose makes approximately UGX 30000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a better business premise. Rose has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 300000 in order to buy a hair dryer and the loan was paid back on time.

Rose is joined in her small group by Harriet K., Sowed N. and Robinah M.. Harriet K. has a business running a grocery store and wants to buy more groceries to sell. Sowed N. is currently operating a business milling maize and wants a loan to stock more maize. Robinah M. operates a business running a grocery store and wants to increase inventory.

loans.use: To purchase more salon equipment to widen customer base

loans.name: Mwanaheri's Mishemishe Group

texts.en:
Mwanaheri is a single 30 year old who owns a small market that she started in 2006. Everyday, she works from 6am to 5pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $35 from her sales.

In the past, Mwanaheri has taken out one successful loan from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business. She now hopes for a loan to buy more food items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members who have businesses selling groceries and food.

loans.use: To buy more items for her business.

loans.name: Bwase East D Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Monica M.. She is currently in the business of poultry farming and is requesting a loan to buy chicken feed. Monica is 25 years old and is single. She has 2 children aged 5 and 8 and both of them go to school. Each week, Monica makes approximately UGX 25000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to boost business. Monica has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 350000 in order to buy more chicken to add to her poultry farm and the loan was paid back on time.

Monica is joined in her small group by Catherine M. and Ephrance K.. Catherine M. has a business running a grocery store and wants to purchase more grocery items. Ephrance K. is currently operating a business running a restaurant and wants a loan to purchase more raw food and cooking ingredients.

loans.use: To boost poultry business

loans.name: Bwase East E Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Amina K.. She is currently in the business of milling maize and is requesting a loan to expand her business. Amina is 30 years old and is married. She has 2 children, aged 5 and 10, and her children go to school. Each week, Amina makes approximately UGX 20000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to educate her children. Amina has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 200000 in order to add to her business and the loan was paid back on time.

Amina is joined in her small group by Betty M. and Regina N.. Betty M. has a business running a restaurant and wants to add to her business. Regina N. is currently operating a business running a retail shop and wants a loan to add stock.

loans.use: To purchase more maize and increase stock

loans.name: Bwase East F Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Elizabeth I.. She is currently in the business of selling new clothes and is requesting a loan to increase her stock of clothes. Elizabeth is 28 years old and is divorced. She has 1 child aged 10, who goes to school. Each week, Elizabeth makes approximately UGX 20000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to create a better business premise. Elizabeth has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 300000 in order to add to her business and the loan was paid back on time.

Elizabeth is joined in her small group by Juliet Samaeyida and Rose B.. Juliet Samaeyida has a business running a restaurant and wants to boost the business. Rose B. is currently operating a business in new clothing sales and wants a loan to purchase more clothes to sell.

loans.use: To add to clothing business

loans.name: Janet

texts.en: Janet O. is a mother of 4 children, 40 years old, and comes from Shibiri, Lagos state, Nigeria. She sells baby products, and has been in her business since 1998. She now needs a loan in the amount of $450 to enable her to buy more baby products to sell. She thanks you.

loans.use: To buy more baby products to sell

loans.name: Tatu's Njinjo B Group

texts.en:
Nuru, 25 years old, has been selling chips for two years. Everyday, she works from 8am to 5pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $40 from her sales.

In the past, Nuru has taken out two successful loans from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business. She now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members who have businesses selling medicine, fish and clothes.

loans.use: To expand her business

loans.name: Ann

texts.en: Ann S. is married with 2 children, is 40 years old, and comes from Shibiri, Lagos state, Nigeria. She rents out plastic chairs & tables for parties and any celebration. She learned how to do this business for 5 years, and she has been in it since 1998. She now needs a loan of $450 to enable her to buy more chairs and tables. This loan will help her serve her customers better. She thanks you.

loans.use: To buy more plastic chairs and table to rent.

loans.name: Asha's Njinjo B Group

texts.en:
Asha B. is 30 years old, married with two children, ages 12 and 6. Asha owns a small kiosk. Everyday, she works from 7am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $70 from her sales.

In the past, Asha has taken out two successful loans from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business. She now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members who have businesses selling fish and general items.

loans.use: To expand her business

loans.name: Katogo D(2056)A Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Lydia B.. She is currently in the business of running a retail shop and is requesting a loan to increase stock. Lydia is 26 years old and married. She has 3 children ranging from age 1.5 to 12 and two of her children go to school.

Lydia is joined in her small group by Deborah Namuddu, Jennifer N., Hadija M., and Elizabeth N.. Deborah Namuddu has a business in poultry farming and wants to purchase poultry feeds. Jennifer N. is currently operating a business in selling used clothes and wants a loan to purchase more clothes for sale. Hadija M. operates a business of beauty parlor and wants to boost business. Elizabeth Namkwaya is currently in the business of used clothing sales and is requesting a loan to increase inventory.

loans.use: To boost retail shop business

loans.name: Adeyemi

texts.en: "LAPO has been a source of financial strength to me," says Mrs. Adeyemi M., who lives in Shibiri, Lagos state, Nigeria. She sells drinks, material & provisions. She has been with LAPO as a client for the past 3 years and been in business since 1987. She needs a loan of $450 to enable her to buy more goods to sell.

loans.use: To buy drinks, material & provisions for sale

loans.name: Katogo D(2056)B Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Justine N.. She is currently in the business of selling new shoes and is requesting a loan to increase stock. Justine is 21 years old and is married. She has 3 children ranging from age 6 months to 3 years and her older two children go to school. With the extra business profits from her loan, Christine hopes to be able to pay the rent for a full-sized shop.

Justine is joined in her small group by Cissy M., Christine N., Sauda B., and Babirye N.. Cissy M. has a business selling fruit and wants to add to her business. Christine N. is currently operating a business selling sweet potatoes and wants a loan to expand businesss. Sauda B. operates a business of new clothing sales and wants to expand business. Babirye N. is currently in the business of making and selling paper bags and is requesting a loan to boost business.

loans.use: To increase inventory in her shoe selling business

loans.name: Cecilia

texts.en: Cicilia M. is 40 years of age, married with 6 children, and lives in Shibiri, Lagos state, Nigeria. She sells drinks, and acquired this business knowledge from her mother. She has been in business since 1988, and needs a loan in the amount of $450 to enable her to buy more drinks to sell. She thanks you.

loans.use: To buy more drinks to sell

loans.name: Rose's Furaha Group

texts.en:
Rose D. is married with three children, ages 21,13 and 5. Rose started selling clothes and beverages two years ago. Everyday, she works from 8am to 10pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $25 from her sales.

In the past, Rose has taken out 2 successful loans from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business. She now hopes for a loan to buy more food items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who have businesses in food vending.

loans.use: To expand her business

loans.name: Kyebando Central A(I) Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Prossy K.. She is currently in the business of operating a restaurant and catering and is requesting a loan to open up a bigger restaurant. Prossy is 34 years old and married. She has 5 children ranging from age 5 to 17 and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, Prossy hopes to be able to pay the school fees for the children.

Prossy is joined in her small group by Ketty N., Mariam N., Catherine N., and Caroline T.. Ketty N. has a business running a restaurant and wants to purchase food warmers. Mariam N. is currently operating a business in charcoal selling and wants a loan to expand to bulk selling. Catherine N. operates a business of charcoal selling and wants to increase her inventory. Caroline T. is currently in the business of selling fish and is requesting a loan to add to her business.

loans.use: To expand restaurant business

loans.name: Ibeyemi

texts.en: Ibeyemi Z. is married with 6 children, is 41years old, and comes from Shibiri, Lagos state, Nigeria. She sells foodstuff & kerosene. She has been in business since 1988 and needs a loan of $450 to enable her to buy more foodstuff and kerosene to sell.

loans.use: To buy foodstuff & kerosene to sell

loans.name: Priscilla

texts.en: Priscilla E. N. is married with 3 children, is 35 years old, and hails from Shibiri, Lagos state, Nigeria. She sells rechargeable cards and makes calls for people. She has been in this business since 2006 and needs a loan of $450 to enable her to buy more rechargeable cards for sales.

loans.use: To buy more rechargeable cards for sales

loans.name: Elizabeth's Furaha Group

texts.en:
Elizabeth, 22 years old, started selling clothes a year ago. Everyday, she works from 8am to 5pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $45 from her sales.

In the past, Elizabeth has taken out two successful loans from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business. She now hopes for a loan to buy more food items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members who have businesses in vegetables and charcoal sales.

loans.use: To expand her business.

loans.name: Kyebando Centra A(Ii) Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Mary N.. She is currently in the business of poultry farming and is requesting a loan to purchase poultry feed. Mary is 48 years old and is a widow. She has 9 children ranging from age 19 to 30 and her children go to school. Each week, Mary makes approximately UGX 30000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to buy laying chicks to add to the broiler chicks she has.

Mary is joined in her small group by Dorothy N., Margret N., Margret T., and Margret N.. Dorothy N. has a business running a beauty parlor and wants to purchase more cosmetics. Margret N. is currently operating a business running a beauty parlor and wants a loan to boost business. Margret T. operates a business of used clothing sales and wants to increase stock. Margret N. is currently in the business of charcoal selling and is requesting a loan to construct a charcoal store/shed.

loans.use: To add to her poultry business

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en: Elizabeth A. is married with 7 children, is 48 years old, and comes from Shibiri, Lagos state, Nigeria. She sells electronics and has been in business since 200. She now needs a loan of $875 to buy more electronics to sell.

loans.use: To buy more electronics for sale

loans.name: Kyebando Central B(I) Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Deborah K.. She is currently in the business of running a grocery store and selling matooke. She is requesting a loan to expand her business. Deborah is 38 years old and is married to her husband, who is a driver for work. She has 1 child of age 15, who goes to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to expand her business.

Deborah is joined in her small group by Alice Bulule, Betty N., Jalia N., and Sylvia N.. Alice Bulule has a business in poultry farming and wants to order more chicks and buy chicken feed. Betty N. is currently operating a beauty parlor business and wants a loan to add to the business. Jalia N. operates a business of selling clod drinks and wants to purchase a fridge. Sylvia N. is currently in the business of carpentry and is requesting a loan to add more working capital.

loans.use: To add to her business and stock more groceries to sell

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en: Victoria U. is married with 2 children, and is 37 years old. She hails from Ajangbadi, Lagos state, Nigeria. She sells rechargeable cards and also makes calls for people. She has been in business since 2003 and needs a loan of $875 to enable her to buy more rechargeable cards in bulk for sales.

loans.use: To buy more rechargeable cards to sell

loans.name: Mwanahawa's Dossy Group

texts.en:
Mwanahawa S. is a single 23 year old who owns a small charcoal store that she started in 2005. Everyday, she works from 7am to 8pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $230 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more food items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members who have businesses as food vendors, shopkeepers, and food and soft drink sellers.

loans.use: To expand her business.

loans.name: Kyebando Central B(Ii) Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Sauda K.. She is currently in the business of running a retail shop and is requesting a loan to purchase more shop items. Sauda is 37 years old and is married to her husband who is an electrician. She has 4 children ranging from age 7 to 21 and her children go to school. Each week, Sauda makes approximately UGX 35000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to save it and buy a plot of land and a house.

Sauda is joined in her small group by Deborah T., Josephine B., Betty A., and Dorcus B.. Deborah T. has a business in carpentry and wants to boost business. Josephine B. is currently operating a retail shop business and wants a loan to purchase a fridge. Betty A. operates a business of selling millet and wants to add more millet to her stock. Dorcus B. is currently in the business of poultry farming and is requesting a loan to purchase chicken feed.

loans.use: To add to a retail shop business

loans.name: Kyebando Central B(Iii) Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Jacinta N.. She is currently in the business of poultry farming and running a restaurant and is requesting a loan to add to her poultry business. Jacinta is 35 years old and is divorced. She has 3 children ranging from age 8 to 12 and her children go to school. Each week, Jacinta makes approximately UGX 35000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay the school fees for her children.

Jacinta is joined in her small group by Asiimwe A., Agatha B., Deborah N., and Faridah N.. Asiimwe A. has a business running a retail shop and wants to add more stock. Agatha B. is currently operating a retail shop business and wants a loan to purchase more shop items. Deborah N. operates a beauty parlor business and wants to boost business. Faridah N. is currently in the business of charcoal selling and is requesting a loan to expand to bulk selling.

loans.use: To boost poultry business

loans.name: Chidima

texts.en: Chidima O. is a 35 year old married woman with 3 children, who lives in Ajangbadi, Lagos, Nigeria. She has been in business since 1993. She now needs a loan in the amount of $700 to enable her to buy more medicine for sales. This loan will help her to serve her customers better.

loans.use: To buy more medicine

loans.name: Chidima

texts.en: Chidima U. is married with 2 children, and she is 25 years of age. She hails from Ajangbadi, Lagos state, Nigeria. She sells drinks, provisions & foodstuff. She has been in business since 1999 and needs a loan of $875 to buy more provisions, drinks and foodstuff for sales. She has been in LAPO for the past 3 years. She thanks you.

loans.use: To buy drinks, provisions & foodstuff for sales.

loans.name: Honoratha's Hekima Group

texts.en:
Honoratha is a 39 years old widow with four children, ages 9 to 21 years old. Honoratha owns a small cafe that she started in 1982. Everyday, she works from 8am to 10pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $290 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more food items to expand her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup member who has a business selling bananas.

loans.use: To expand business

loans.name: Kyebando Central B(Iv) Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Agnes N.. She is currently in the business of running a retail shop and is requesting a loan to add more stock. Agnes is 32 years old and married. She has 4 children ranging from age 1 to 9 and her children go to school. Each week, Agnes makes approximately UGX 50000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to save it and add to her business.

Agnes is joined in her small group by Safina N., Cissy N., Rose N., and Mariam N.. Safina N. has a business selling fish and wants to expand her business. Cissy N. is currently operating a business running a grocery store and wants a loan to increase her inventory. Rose N. operates a tailoring business and wants to purchase a sewing machine and more cloth fabrics. Mariam N. is currently in the business of operating a restaurant and is requesting a loan to purchase more food and utensils.

loans.use: To purchase more shop items and expand business

loans.name: Chinasa

texts.en: Chinasa O. is a 34 year old married woman with 3 children, who lives in Shibiri, Lagos state, Nigeria. She sells material & tailoring supplies. She has been in business since 2004 and needs a loan of $875 to enable her to buy more tailoring supplies & material for sales.

loans.use: To buy more material & tailoring supplies for sales

loans.name: Kyebando Central B(V) Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Florence N.. She is currently in the business of operating a drug shop and is requesting a loan to purchase more drugs to sell. Florence is 32 years old and is married. She has 3 children ranging from age 4 to 8 and her children go to school. Each week, Florence makes approximately UGX 80000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to expand her drug shop business by buying more drugs.

Florence is joined in her small group by Immaculate N., Jane N., Abesach A., and Kevin Namwanje. Immaculate N. has a business in charcoal selling and wants to expand to bulk selling. Jane N. is currently operating a business in selling snacks and wants a loan to buy a microwave for warming snacks. Abesach A. operates a business running a beauty parlor and wants to purchase a greater variety of cosmetics. Kevin Namwanje is currently in the business of running a restaurant and is requesting a loan to buy food warmers and utensils.

loans.use: To boost drug shop business buy purchasing more drugs

loans.name: Grace

texts.en: Grace O. is a married woman of 41, with 6 children, and she comes from Shibiri, Lagos state, Nigeria. She sells cloth & tailoring materials. She has been in this business since 1988 and needs a loan of $450 to enable her to buy more goods for sales.

loans.use: To buy more cloth & tailoring materials for sales

loans.name: Dike

texts.en: Dike N. is a single lady, 26 years of age, and hails from the Ojo Igbede area in Lagos state, Nigeria. She is a fashion designer and also sells cloth and bakes cakes for sale. She has been with LAPO for the past 2 years and needs a loan of $875 to enable her to buy more cloth for sales.

loans.use: To buy more cloth for sales

loans.name: Magamaga Central C Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Safia N.. She is currently in the business of selling chapati and is requesting a loan to add to her business by buying more baking flour and eggs. Safia is 40 years old and is married. She has 7 children ranging from age 9 to 26 and her children go to school. Each week, Safia makes approximately UGX 25000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to educate her children. Safia has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 300000 in order to add to her business and the loan was paid back on time.

Safia is joined in her small group by Hajirah Aliwebwa. Hajirah Aliwebwa has a business in used clothing sales and wants to purchase more clothes to sell.

loans.use: To expand chapati business

loans.name: Temitope

texts.en: Temitope M. is 25 years old. She lives in Isashi, Lagos State, in Nigeria. Temitope supplies nylon to women in her community. She needs a loan of $450 to enable her to purchase more nylon to sell.

loans.use: To buy more nylon for sale.

loans.name: Magamaga Central B Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Feda N.. She is currently in the nursery seedling business and is requesting a loan to buy more farm equipment like watering cans. Feda is 38 years old and married. Her husband is a librarian. She has 5 children ranging from age 8 to 21 and her children go to school. Each week, Feda makes approximately UGX 30000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to add more to her business. Feda has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 400000 in order to add to her business and the loan was paid back on time.

Feda is joined in her small group by Janet K.. Janet K. has a business in charcoal selling and wants to expand to bulk selling.

loans.use: To add to seedlings business

loans.name: Dorcas

texts.en: Dorcas O. is a mother of 7, married and is 45 years old. She lives in Isashi, Lagos state, Nigeria. She sells kitchen supplies and has been in business for over 5 years. She needs a loan of $450 to enable her to purchase more kitchen utensils to sell.

loans.use: To buy more kitchen utensils.

loans.name: Kate

texts.en: Kate A. is 30 years old, has 3 children, and comes from Shibiri, Lagos state, Nigeria. She is a fashion designer and has been in this business since 2006. She needs a loan of $275 to enable her to buy more cloth and tailoring materials to sell.

loans.use: To buy cloth and tailoring materials for sale

loans.name: Carlos

texts.en:
Carlos R. is a blacksmith who has been working in this area for over 13 years.  He currently works out of his house and works very hard to support his family--he is married with five children.  With the loan of $375, Carlos will buy a semi-industrial cutting machine for his business.  

With access to better machinery Carlos will be able to make and fix items faster and with more efficiency. This will increase his earnings and help put his children through school.

loans.use: To buy machinery for his blacksmithing business

loans.name: Sara Melita

texts.es:
Sara Melita lives in the Juanji district in the province of Mariscal Cáceres. She sells food and drinks in her home. Most of her customers are soldiers and army officers.

She's had this business for 10 years and it has permitted her to help her husband with the household expenses. She was invited by a friend to Banco Central's "Honesty and Work" after Sara realized she needed capital to increase sales. WIth the first loan she was able to start her business with just a table and chair, and then eventually it grew little by little.

With the loan of 1800 soles, she will buy items for her business such as a bag of sugar, a bag of rice, hundreds of fruits and a motor for her refrigerator.

Sara is the 50 year old mother of three children. Two of them still live with her and the other is independent. She lives with her husband who supports her and the family. Thanks to the good sales they've been having, she's been able to fix the house and take care of her children's education. She intends to renovate her business.

Translated by Beatriz Yuste, Kiva Volunteer .

La sra. Sara Melita vive en la provincia de Mariscal Cáceres distrito de Juanjui, se dedica a la venta de comida y refrigerios, su negocio esta ubicado en un espacio de su casa, sus principales clientes son militares y oficiales del ejercito quienes son los que consumen mas en su negocio.

Tiene dedicándose al negocio 10 años, el mismo que le ha permitido apoyar a su esposo con los gastos del hogar. Necesitaba contar con capital para incrementar sus ventas es así que una amiga la invita al BC “Honestidad y Trabajo” con el primer préstamo empezó a trabajar pudo ampliar poco a poco el negocio que inicio con una mesita y una silla fuera de su casa.

Con el préstamo de S/.1800.00 el cual será cancelado en 6 meses, comprará artículos para su negocio como 01 saco de azúcar, 01 saco de arroz, frutas en cientos, un motor para su refrigeradora y otros.

La señora Sara Melita, tiene 50 años, 03 hijos de los cuales 02 están aún a su cargo y 01 ya es independiente, vive con su esposo que es el apoyo para ella y su familia, gracias a las buenas ventas que esta teniendo a podido arreglar su casa y velar por la educación de sus hijos, tiene proyectado acondicionar mejor su local de ventas.

loans.use: To buy items for her business like a bag of sugar, a bag of rice, hundreds of fruits and a motor for her refrigerator.

loans.name: Alvina

texts.es:
Mrs. Alvina lives in the province of Marshal Cáceres district of Juanjui. She works selling food in the Nº 02 market of the district.

She has been dedicated to the business for 9 years. Her first business was not yielding good results. There were days that she did not sell anything and she had to pay the household expenses, but could not even pay the rent. So a friend gave her the idea of selling food in the country house where she lived and she began selling cebiche (a seafood dish) and other dishes, with good results. She decided then to leave the business of selling vegetables and to sell food in the place she already had in the market. This is how she began. She needed more capital to be able to expand and to continue with the business now that she did not lack for clients. A friend invited her to the "Union and Work" Communal Bank, to which she now belongs.

With the recent loan of 500 soles which will be paid off in 4 months, she will buy articles for her business such as 1 bag of rice, 1 bag of sugar, kilograms of stew, oil and meat for the preparation of dishes.

Señora Sara Alvina is 44 years old and has 2 children of which 1 is still is in her care. She lives with her husband who supports her and with whom she works in the business of selling food. At present they have two positions for selling food and one of their projects this to acquire another position with the new loan that she wishes to receive.

Translated from Spanish by B, Kiva Volunteer.

La sra. Alvina vive en la provincia de Mariscal Cáceres distrito de Juanjui, se dedica a la venta de comida en el mercado Nº 02 del distrito.

Tiene dedicándose al negocio 09 años, su primer negocio no le estaba rindiendo buenos resultados, había días que no vendía nada y tenia que pagar los gastos de su casa, no le alcanzaba para pagar el alquiler ; es así que una amiga le da la idea de vender comida en la quinta donde vivía y empezó vendiendo cebiche y otros platos, dándole buenos resultados, decidió entonces dejar el negocio de la venta de verduras y vender comida en el puesto que ya tenía en el mercado; es así como empezó. Necesitaba de más capital para poder ampliar y continuar con el negocio ya que los que clientes no le faltan, entonces una amiga la invita al Banco Comunal ”Unión y Trabajo” al que pertenece actualmente.

Con el reciente préstamo de S/.500.00 el cual será cancelado en 4 meses, comprará artículos para su negocio como son 01 saco de arroz, 01 saco de azúcar, menestras en kilos, aceite y carne para los preparativos.

La señora Sara Alvina, tiene 44 años, 02 hijos de los cuales 01 aún está a su cargo, vive con su esposo quien la apoya y con quien trabaja en el negocio de la venta de comida, actualmente tiene dos puestos de venta de comida y dentro de sus proyectos esta el adquirir otro puesto de ventas con el nuevo préstamo que desea recibir.

loans.use: To buy one bag of rice, one bag of sugar, kilograms of stew, oil and meat for the preparation of food for sale.  Also to purchase an additional position for selling foods.

loans.name: Edith

texts.en:
Edith G. is 37 years old and runs a small butcher shop and convenience store with her husband. They have been running this convenience store for 10 years and it has successfully earned enough income for her small family of three.

Edith manages the stock in the convenience store and her husband runs the small butcher shop. Over the years they have built up a large number of customers and are in a great location. Edit is asking for a loan of $650, which she will use to invest in more merchandise for her convenience store.

loans.use: To buy merchandise for her convenience store like milk, rice, sugar, yerba, and pasta

loans.name: Dory

texts.es:
Dory lives in the district of Juanji in the province of Mariscal de Cáceres. She sells fruits and vegetables in the district's number 2 market.

She's been in business for 10 years. The idea to start the business came out of the fact that the family was in need and she wanted to help cover household expenses. She started selling small quantities of fruits and vegetables outside the market, which she had collected from her parents garden. Then a friend invited her to Banco Central's "Honesty and Work" to ask for a loan so she could rent a kiosk at the market and buy items to help her begin selling her produce.

With the recent loan of 3000 soles, which will be repaid in 6 months, she'll buy items for her business such as bags of oranges, yuca, onion, potatoes, flour, boxes of papaya, bananas and other.

Sara Dory is a 44-year-old mother of two. She lives with her husband who is supportive of her and who himself works with some businesses. She plans to buy land so she can build a house.

Translated by Beatriz Yuste, Kiva Volunteer.

La sra. Dory vive en la provincia de Mariscal Cáceres distrito de Juanjui, se dedica a la venta de frutas y verduras en el mercado Nº 02 del distrito.

Tiene dedicándose al negocio 10 años, la idea del negocio surgió a raíz de la necesidad que estaba pasando su familia ,quería poder a poyar con los gastos del hogar, es así que empezó vendiendo frutas en pequeñas cantidades que traía de la chacra de sus padres a las afueras del mercado, una amiga la invito al Banco Comunal “Honestidad y Trabajo” para que pida un préstamo y pueda comprar algunos utensilios para la venta y alquilar un espacio dentro del mercado.

Con el reciente préstamo de S/.3000.00 el cual será cancelado en 6 meses, comprará artículos para su negocio como sacos de naranja, yuca, cebolla, papa, harina, cajas de papaya, racimos de plátano y otros.

La señora Sara Dory, tiene 44 años, 02 hijos de los cuales los 02 aún están a su cargo, vive con su esposo quien la apoya y con quien trabaja en algunos negocios, tiene proyectado comprar un terreno para construir su casa.

loans.use: To buy bags of oranges, yuca, onion, potatoes, flour and other

loans.name: Felipa

texts.en:
Felipa O. is a hardworking mother of two. She is currently working in a small convenience store which she runs out of her house. Her husband is a successful baker. He used to sell baked goods out of their house but now he works at a local supermarket baking their breads and sweet treats.

Through his work, Felipa was able to open her own small convenience store at their house, and with the combined incomes, they can support their two children. Felipa is asking for a loan of $225 to buy cooking oil, meats, eggs, and other popular food items. With a greater variety of food, she is hoping her profits will increase.

loans.use: To buy foostuffs for her convenience store

loans.name: Maritza

texts.es:
Maritza lives in the district of Pajarillo in the province of Mariscal Caceres. She sells food products and other items in a small equipped space in her house.

She's had her business for a year and a half now. IT all started when a friend from her district invited Maritza to join the Banco Central's "Unión y Trabajo" so she could start her business. Now, little by little, she's been growing and expanding her small business.

With the recent loan of 800 soles (3 soles = $1) from Manuela Ramos, which will be repaid in full in 6 months, she bought items for her business such as a bag of rice, a bag of sugar, mixed vegetables by the kilo, oil, toilet paper, detergent, bread, eggs and other.

Maritza is a 28-year-old single mother of an 18-month-old baby. She stilll lives with her parents whom she supports with her small business, and they support her too. She plans to increase the space of her small grocery store, thanks to the support of loyal customers in her community, whom she serves with a smile -- and it shows in her sales.

Translated by Beatriz Yuste, Kiva Volunteer.

La sra. Maritza vive en la provincia de Mariscal Cáceres distrito de Pajarillo, se dedica a la venta abarrotes en un pequeño espacio acondicionado en su casa.

Tiene actualmente dedicándose al negocio 01 año y medio, tiempo de permanencia en el B.C.”Unión y Trabajo”, donde una amiga del distrito la invita a pertenecer al mencionado banco para que empiece su negocio, es así que ella llega a ingresar al banco, donde escalando de a pocos esta acondicionando y ampliando su pequeño negocio.

Con el reciente préstamo recibido de Manuela Ramos de S/.800.00 el cual será cancelado en 6 meses, compró artículos para su negocio como son 01 saco de arroz, 01 saco de azúcar, menestras en kilos, aceite, papel higiénico, detergente, panes, huevos y otros.

La señora Maritza, tiene 28 años y 01 pequeña hija de 01 año y medio, es madre soltera y vive aún con sus padres a quienes apoya con su pequeño negocio y quienes también la apoyan, dentro de sus proyectos esta el ampliar su pequeña bodega, gracias a que en el pueblo cuenta con buenos clientes a quienes atiende amablemente y sus ventas le están respondiendo

loans.use: To buy rice, sugar, mixed vegetables and other.

loans.name: Graciela

texts.en:
Graciela Ester F. is a mother of two. She runs a small grocery store in Ciudad del Este. She has been in business for 6 years and her income, along with her husband’s income for construction work, is enough to support the family. She would like to see her grocery store prosper but can only do so with a small loan.

Graciela would like a loan of $425 to buy more stock for her store including more foodstuffs like sugar, oil, eggs, and milk. Her husband at times goes into the bordering country of Brazil to buy cheaper goods. This loan will help their business and their humble incomes grow, and help to put their children through school.

loans.use: To buy food merchandise like sugar, eggs, milk, meat, and pasta for resale

loans.name: Rahima

texts.en: Rahima is 39 year old woman from Zukići, a small village near the town Živinice. She is divorced and she works as a cook in a primary school near Živinice. Her monthly salary is 320 KM and that is not enough to buy seeds for sowing. She is doing crop husbandry and she is going to use this loan in the amount of 600 KM for seeds. She hopes that her business activity will be successful in order to increase household income.

loans.use: For buying seeds.

loans.name: Ushirikiano B Group

texts.en:
Saumu S., age 41, is married with 2 children (ages 16 and 9) She owns a business of selling clothes which she began 8 years ago. She works from 10am to 6pm daily making a monthly profit of around US$87.

In the past Saum has taken out 3 loans from Tujijenge Tanzania to buy more clothes for sale. She hopes for a new loan to open a shop for her business. She will share this loan with her sub-group members who are selling foods and clothes.

In the picture, Saum is in the middle back row.

loans.use: Open a shop for selling clothes

loans.name: Hugo

texts.en: Thanks to Hugo E.’s tenacity, entrepreneurial spirit, and his effort, he has made a prosperous business for himself.  He works delivering goods with his truck.  However, his only source of income needs repairs and he needs a loan of $425 to make the necessary repairs to his vehicle.  He will then be able continue his work and continue making an income.  He is a young man of 26 and just beginning in the business world.  Someday he hopes to have enough money to settle down and have a family.

loans.use: To repair his delivery truck

loans.name: Daniel

texts.es:
Daniel, his wife and their child live at his uncle and aunt's place on Luis Lara Street in the San Pedro area of the city of La Paz.

He has a car that doubles as a taxi in the daytime; his wife travels to take vegetables to sell to the small-scale vendors at the Rodrigues market, so she can add to the household income.

The loan they are asking for now is to repair and maintain his taxi, so he can continue working without fail.

His credit history is in good standing which qualifies him for another loan. Daniel has been a client of IMPRO since June 2006.

Translated by Beatriz Yuste, Kiva Volunteer.

Daniel vive en casa de sus tíos con su esposa e hijo en la calle Luis Lara de la zona de San Pedro de la ciudad de La Paz.

Tiene un auto el cual lo trabaja como taxi durante todo el día; su esposa viaja y trae verdura para vender en el mercado Rodrigues a las comerciantes minoristas y de esta manera ayuda en los ingresos del hogar.

El crédito que solicitan ahora es para la reparación y mantenimiento del taxi y poder seguir trabajando con normalidad.

Su antecedente histórico lo califica como buen cliente y puede acceder a un nuevo crédito. Daniel es cliente de IMPRO desde Junio de 2006.

loans.use: To repair and maintain his taxi.

loans.name: Džemila

texts.en: Džemila is from Zukići, a small village near the town Živinice. She was born in 1973 and she is married. Džemila has two children, 10 and 16 years old.  She breeds strawberries and she intends to use this loan, in the amount of 800 KM, for buying nylon for strawberry seedlings. As she is experienced in strawberry breeding, she believes that expanding her business will help her earn additional income for the household.

loans.use: For buying nylon.

loans.name: Anna

texts.en:
Anna S. is an entrepreneur from Khoost in the far western tip of Ukraine. She runs a small women’s clothing sales business from a little space at a store “Artem” in Khoost. Anna is no stranger to difficult times. She and her husband, Nicolai, have had to deal with the tragedy of losing their only daughter. They have also lived through the challenges and uncertainties of the collapse of the Soviet Union and the new opportunities provided by an independent Ukraine. Anna started her business 3 years ago when faced with difficult life circumstances. Since that time she has done well and now makes around $1200 per month, a very good wage for her and her husband.

Anna has requested a loan of $700 to increase her working capital. In the future she hopes to expand her business by opening a second sales location. This loan will allow Anna to continue to make investments in her business and ensure its stability.

loans.use: Increase working capital

loans.name: Irma

texts.en:
Irma Flietas not only runs a hair styling salon, she also has students who study the art of hair styling with her. They later go on to open their own salons. She is a single mother and lives in the city of Ciudad del Este. One of her daughters is also a hair stylist and works with her.

Since she was a young girl, Irma has been styling hair because it is her passion. She is asking for a loan of $650 today to buy materials to keep her salon and school running. She will use the loan to buy shampoos, gels, scissors, and other styling implements.

loans.use: To buy products for her hair salon including hair dye, shampoo, and other hair styling supplies

loans.name: Ivan

texts.en:
Ivan has a small business at the central market in Khoost, Ukraine where he sells a variety of toys and plastic goods. His business is the main source of income for his family of three. Ivan and his wife, Oksana, have one son. Ivan has been in business for about eight years. The plastic products he sells are practical and can be used in every home. He currently makes about $200 in profit each month but would like to increase his income so he can better provide for his family.

Ivan has requested a five-month loan of $800 to increase his working business capital. We are happy for the opportunity to assist this goal-oriented husband and father with his business livelihood.

loans.use: Incrrease working capital

loans.name: Justina

texts.en:
Justina is a single mother of three children. She and her mother sold a piece of land and bought another piece of property in Ciudad del Este, where they started their own clothing business. With the profits from the business Justina has since paid her mother back.

Justina has been in business now for 7 years. It is successful and brings in enough money for Justina to support her children. However, she would like to expand her business by purchasing more jeans to sell to both to men and women, and clothing for school-age children. By increasing the variety of clothing for sale, she will be able to increase her earnings.

loans.use: To buy jeans for resale in her clothing business

loans.name: Cesar

texts.es:
Cesar lives in his house with his wife and children on Mariscal Santa Cruz Street in the Obispo Bosque area in the city of La Paz.

Cesar makes seasonal clothing and his wife makes shawls and also walks around selling plastic products. Cesar received his first loan through Kiva, which he repaid on time.

The loan Cesar is asking for now is to buy fabric so he can continue with his business which has grown continuously. He needs to buy materials like fabric, thread, lining, etc., in greater quantities so he can take advantage of lower prices.

His credit history is in good standing which qualifies him for a new loan.

Translated by Beatriz Yuste, Kiva Volunteer.

Cesar vive en casa propia con su esposa e hijos en la calle Mariscal Santa Cruz de la zona de Obispo Bosque de la ciudad de La Paz.

Cesar se dedica a la confección de ropa de temporada, la esposa confecciona mantillas y al mismo tiempo ambula vendiendo productos de plástico; Cesar ya obtuvo un crédito anterior a través de Kiva el cual fue cancelado puntualmente.

El crédito que solicita ahora es para comprar material y seguir con su negocio, el mismo que ha tenido un crecimiento sostenido y necesitan comprar el material, como ser telas, hilos, forros, etc. en mayores cantidades para aprovechar los precios más bajos.

Su antecedente histórico lo califica como buen cliente y puede acceder a un nuevo crédito.

loans.use: To buy fabric, thread and lining for his clothing store.

loans.name: Virginia

texts.es:
Virginia and her children live in a rental on Pinos Street in the Pasankeri area of the city of La Paz. She's a single mother who works as a maid, but her small salary isn't enough. That's why she decided to start a small-scale business and the loan she is asking for is starter capital to begin selling school supplies.

She doesn't have any credit history with IMPRO, but she qualifies for one because of her desire to better herself and the social aspect of our institution.

Translated by Beatriz Yuste, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Virginia vive en alquiler en la calle los pinos de la zona de Pasankeri de la ciudad de La Paz con sus hijos; es madre soltera y trabaja como empleada domestica pero su sueldo es muy poco y no le alcanza por lo cual decidió dedicarse al comercio minorista y el crédito que solicita es para capital de arranque y empezara su negocio vendiendo material escolar. No tiene antecedente Histórico con Impro pero califica para acceder a uno por su deseo de superación y por el carácter social que tiene nuestra Institución

loans.use: To buy school supplies like notebooks, pencils, pens, etc., for her business.

loans.name: Martha

texts.en:
Martha has been members of the “Tulipanes” community bank for three years. She mentioned that, in the community bank, she has learned to be punctual, responsible, learned how to manage her businesses, how to improve her relationship with her husband and, above all, to save.

Martha is 37 years old. She is married and has three children. Martha owns a tailor shop located in her house. She has been running this business for three years. She originally learned to sew from her aunt. Later, she perfected has ability by studying at a trade school and working in a tailor shop owned by someone else. Martha started out with only one machine, but now has four.

Martha needs a loan of 1000 soles (3 soles = $1) to invest in fabric, thread, and buttons, and to pay laborers.

One of the most important aspects of the community bank is the interest-earning savings account that each associate has. Maria plans to use her savings to make more capital available to her business. Her dream is to have a successful business, and that her children will be professionals.

Click here to see Martha's latest loan.

loans.use: Martha needs a loan of 1000 soles (3 soles = $1) to buy fabric, thread, and buttons, and to pay laborers.

loans.name: Deonisia's Group

texts.en:
Jannett, Delia and Deonesia have been members of the “Tulipanes” community bank for between one and two years. In the community bank, they have learned to save, be responsible, be punctual, be aware of their rights as women, and learned how to treat their children as well as their clients.

Jannett is 20 years old. She and her brother own a metal works shop. In addition, Jannett is studying cosmetology.

Delia is 28 years old. She lives with her partner and two children who are ages twelve and three. Delia has been selling clothing for one year. She takes orders from her friends and family and then goes to Lima to buy the products.

Deonesia is 40 years old. She is married and has four children between the ages of seven and twenty-two. With her husband, Deonesia upholsters auto seats. They travel to Lima to buy parts for their business.

Jannett, Delia and Deonesia need loans of 1000, 1000, and 1200 soles respectively (3 soles = $1), which they will use to buy pants, shirts, blouses, and upholstery materials.

One of the most important aspects of the community bank is the interest-earning savings account each associate has. Jannett, Delia and Deonesia plan to use their savings for emergencies, to buy land, and to cover medical expenses. Their dreams are to open a beauty salon, help their families, own a home, have stable businesses, and that their children will be professionals.

loans.use: Jannett, Delia and Deonesia need loans of 1000, 1000, and 1200 soles (3 soles = $1), which they will use to buy pants, shirts, blouses, and upholstery materials.

loans.name: Francisca

texts.en:
Francisca has been an associate of the “Chontaca” community bank for one year. She mentioned that the bank organizer has taught her how to invest her money, how to manage her business, and how to care for her children.

Francisca sells motor oil and gasoline from her home. She started this business because her husband is a mechanic, and she noticed that there was a demand for these items. She started the business and, since joining the community bank, has been able to expand her selection. Francisca also grows vegetables and raises animals that she later sells to middle men that visit her village.

Francisca needs a loan of 3000 soles (3 soles = $1), which she will invest in buying motor oil and gasoline.

One of the most important aspects of the community bank is the interest-earning savings account each associate has. Francisca plans to use her savings in the case of an emergency and to pay for her children’s education. Her dream is that her children receive a good education, that her business continues to grow, and to open a mechanic shop with modern machinery.

loans.use: Francisca needs a loan of 3000 soles (3 soles = $1), which she will invest in buying motor oil and gasoline.

loans.name: Julia Demetria's Group

texts.en:
Epifania, Maria, and Julia have been members of the “Tulipanes” community bank for over one year. As part of the community bank, they have learned to be responsible, manage their time, learned how to educate their children, and the importance of saving.

Epifania is 54years old. She is married and has ten children, four of whom live with her. Epifania runs a store where she sells food staples such as rice, flour, and sugar. She also sells fruits and vegetables.

Maria is 26 years old. She lives with her partner and five year old son. Maria rents a space in the town center where she sells food staples. She has been running this business for three years.

Julia is 30 years old. She lives with her partner and two children. Julia sells vegetables in the Nery Garcia market. She buys the vegetables in bulk from the nearby jungle region and then transports them to Ayacucho.

Epifania, Maria, and Julia need loans of 400, 1200, and 600 soles (3 soles = $1), which they will invest in buying milk, noodles, soft drinks, soaps, shampoo, sugar, rice, oil, sweet potatoes and lemons.

One of the most important aspects of the community bank is the interest-earning savings account that each associate has. Epifania, Maria and Julia plan to use their savings to buy land, pay for their children’s education, and to increase the capital available for their businesses. Their dreams are to buy land, own a home, and help their children move forward and become professionals.

loans.use: Epifania, Maria, and Julia need loans of 400, 1200, and 600 soles (3 soles = $1), which they will invest in buying milk, noodles, soft drinks, soaps, shampoo, sugar, rice, oil, sweet potatoes and lemons.

loans.name: Ana María

texts.es:
The local store in the El Sauce municipality of the city of León is very important because it fills the basic needs of the people. Ana Maria P. has had her business for 10 years in the same location in the municipality of El Sauce.

It is important to stress the fact that despite life's hardships, she has been able to go on to help her husband with the maintenance of the household and school fees for her two children whom she loves. Today, her biggest concern is to urgently acquire merchandise for her store so she can continue the upkeep of the household. Previously, when she was in need, she wisely went to Ceprodel who gave her credit which she used to buy her products.

Beatriz Yuste, Kiva Volunteer.

El negocio de pulpería en el municipio El Sauce de la ciudad de León es de mucha importancia porque a diario las personas hacen uso de estas para suplir la necesidad por la que pasan. La señora Ana Maria P. se dedica a este negocio desde hace 10 años siempre teniéndolo ubicado en el municipio de El Sauce.

Es de interés plantear que a pesar de las adversidades de la vida, ella ha logrado salir adelante para apoyar a su esposo con el sustento del hogar y pago del colegio de sus dos hijos que tanto ama. Hoy en día su mayor necesidad es la urgencia de adquirir los productos de pulpería para lograr continuar manteniendo su hogar. Para esto, muy sabiamente anteriormente ha acudido a Ceprodel quien le ha brindado créditos que los ha utilizado en la compra de sus productos.

loans.use: To buy merchandise.

loans.name: Emilia's Group

texts.en:
Emilia, Aydee, and Maria have been members of the “Chontaca” community bank for one year. They all live in the small town of Chantaca, which is located two hours outside of the city of Ayacucho. Emilia, Aydee, and Maria mentioned that, in the community bank, they have learned to be punctual, responsible, to avoid domestic violence, and to save.

Emilia is 26 years old. She lives with her partner and two children. Emilia sells candy in her husband’s mechanic shop. She also sells replacement car parts. She started this business one year ago with her first loan from the community bank.

Aydee is 23 years old. She lives with her partner and two children. Aydee buys and sells young animals. She buys them in various small daily markets and then sells them at the regional Sunday market.

Maria is 31 years old. She is a widow and has four children. Maria has a well stocked store where she sells food staples such as rice, sugar, and flour, as well as fruits and vegetables.

Emilia, Aydee, and Maria each need loans of 1000 soles (3 soles = $1) which they will invest in buying oil, car parts, cookies, soft drinks, pork, lamb, sugar, rice, flour, vegetables, and fruits.

One of the most important aspects of the community bank is the interest-earning savings account that each associate has. Emilia, Aydee, and Maria plan to use their savings to improve their businesses and to pay for their children’s education. Their dreams are to increase their businesses, build a house in the city of Ayacucho, and that their children will be professionals.

loans.use: Emilia, Aydee, and Maria each need loans of 1000 soles (3 soles = $1) which they will invest in buying oil, car parts, cookies, soft drinks, pork, lamb, sugar, rice, flour, vegetables, and fruits.

loans.name: Arelis Del Carmen

texts.es:
Arelis has been selling merchandise for more than 3 years. This came about while she was working as a maid and her small salary wasn't enough to cover expenses. She decided to invest her money in buying merchandise that she could sell in order to improve her situation and help her spouse with household expenses and school fees for her son. She's asking for a loan from CEPRODEL, who has previously extended a friendly hand by financing her business, which resulted in increased sales and increased income for her household.

Presently, her dream is to better the conditions of her premises and her business so she can continue providing daily financial support to the household.

Translated by Beatriz Yuste, Kiva Volunteer.

La Señora Arelis se dedica a la actividad de venta de productos de pulpería desde hace mas de tres años e inicia esta actividad por iniciativa de que al dedicarse solamente al trabajo de ama de casa no le resultaba ya que los ingresos disminuían cada día mas y por tal razón decide invertir en la compra de sus productos para mejorar su situación y apoyar a su esposo en los gastos de su hogar y pago de colegio de su hijo. Solicita préstamo a CEPRODEL quien le extiende su mano amiga y le financia para su negocio obteniendo considerables mejoras que han permitido mejores ingresos para su hogar.

Actualmente su mayor sueño es mejorar las condiciones de su local y seguir en su negocio que le ha permitido obtener también el sustento diario de su familia.

loans.use: To buy merchandise.

loans.name: Aura María

texts.es:
Aura María C. is a married mother of 3 children who are all in school. She began her sherbet (ices) business 10 years ago, selling her icy treats on bicycle around the streets of the El Sauce municipality in the city of León.

Today, in order to get ahead and be able to offer her dear children an education, Aura María puts great effort into working every day and despite the exposure to the sun and the physical exhaustion from bicyling, she's been able to succeed in her business.

For 3 years she has been receiving loans from CEPRODEL which have greatly helped her. She was able to buy ice cream for resale and saved money with which she hopes to one day buy her own store where she will sell sherbet.

Translated by Beatriz Yuste, Kiva Volunteer.

Aura Maria C. es una madre casada y con 3 hijos de los cuales todos estudian, algunos en la primaria y otros en la secundaria. Desde hace 10 años inició su negocio de venta de sorbetes (helados) realizando sus ventas ambulantemente en una bicicleta donde recorre todas las calles del municipio El Sauce en la ciudad de León.

Hoy en día, para poder salir adelante y brindarle la educación a sus queridos hijos, la señora Esperanza se esfuerza grandemente trabajando todos los días y a pesar de la exposición al sol y el desgaste físico por vender ambulantemente en la bicicleta, ha logrado salir adelante en el negocio.

Desde hace 3 años ha realizado créditos con Ceprodel y según cuenta le han sido de muchísimo beneficio porque ha logrado comprar los helados para luego venderlos y de igual manera ha ahorrado para algún día tener su propio local donde vender los sorbetes.

loans.use: To buy ice cream

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en:
Victoria belongs to the “Tulipanes” community bank. She has been a member for two years. She mentioned that, in the community bank, she has learned to be punctual, responsible, how to manage her businesses, how to improve her relationship with her husband and, above all, to save.

Victoria is 69 years old. She is a widow and has seven children, two of whom live with her.
